head.title: His Collapse A Memory, Van de Velde Back in Hunt

hedline.hl1: His Collapse A Memory, Van de Velde Back in Hunt

abstract.p: Jean Van de Velde is in contention at British Open, one year after squandering three-stroke lead (S)

block.p: One year after his biggest nightmare, Jean Van de Velde is dreaming again about winning the British Open.

He had one of the worst collapses in golf history last year, making a triple-bogey on the 72nd hole at the British Open, squandering a three-stroke lead and eventually losing to Paul Lawrie in a three-way playoff with Justin Leonard. But with a four-under-par 68 today, coupled with his opening-round 71, Van de Velde was in contention again at five under par, six strokes behind Tiger Woods, the leader. After making a bogey on the No. 17 Road Hole, Van de Velde ended with momentum, making a 10-foot birdie putt at No. 18.
One year after his biggest nightmare, Jean Van de Velde is dreaming again about winning the British Open.

He had one of the worst collapses in golf history last year, making a triple-bogey on the 72nd hole at the British Open, squandering a three-stroke lead and eventually losing to Paul Lawrie in a three-way playoff with Justin Leonard. But with a four-under-par 68 today, coupled with his opening-round 71, Van de Velde was in contention again at five under par, six strokes behind Tiger Woods, the leader. After making a bogey on the No. 17 Road Hole, Van de Velde ended with momentum, making a 10-foot birdie putt at No. 18.
''My problem over the next 24 hours will be relaxing,'' said Van de Velde, who led by one stroke through 36 holes last year and by five strokes after 54 holes.
Many people wondered how Van de Velde would handle such a devastating loss, but he has handled it with honesty and humor, becoming one of the sport's most popular players.
Van de Velde could not resist when someone asked what he thought about his chances. ''Anything can happen with 36 to go,'' he said. ''Even with one hole to go.''

Playing primarily on the PGA Tour this year, Van de Velde, a Frenchman, is 86th on the money list, and he tied for second at the Tucson Open. He will be a sentimental favorite this weekend, and he hoped the support would spur him on.
''The last three or four weeks I was very tired, but here I seem to have more energy somehow,'' Van de Velde said. ''My reception has been fantastic. But it has been like that everywhere I go.''
Different Story for Lawrie

Paul Lawrie, the defending champion, did not come close to making the cut at even par, finishing at nine over. A native of Scotland, Lawrie said he would probably not watch the weekend action on television.
''Maybe a little on Sunday, but I don't watch much golf,'' he said. ''I'm going to take a few weeks. My year has been very frustrating.''
Toms Shows He Belongs
David Toms, at eight under par, has made a strong showing in his first British Open. He will play in Saturday's final group with Tiger Woods.

''I've played well in the States all year, but I didn't really know what to expect from the course,'' Toms, a native of Louisiana, said. ''My first goal was to play on the weekend. I've played solid.''
Toms played well enough to earn an exemption from qualifying for this year's tournament. In past years, he decided against trying to earn his way in through a qualifying tournament.
''Looking at the whole experience, I guess I was a little cheap over the years,'' he said. ''I did not want to come over here and spend the money to qualify. Looking back, I wish I would have.''
Duval's Back Is Aching

David Duval (70-70, four under par) has played the entire British Open with a sore back, which flared up Tuesday. He has been moving gingerly on the course, particularly when he reaches into the cup to pick up his ball.

''If it was any other event, I would probably not be playing,'' he said. ''I really don't know what is wrong with it, and I'm trying not to focus on it. I wish it was a different circumstance, but it's what I've been dealt this week. It has been bothering me quite a bit. I guess I simply strained my back. It's just like a sprained ankle.''
